awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: Removing Bottlenecks in High Performance Computational Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational chemistry has become ubiquitous throughout the fields of science and engineering. Among the many uses of computational chemistry codes are to aid in the design of new materials with specific properties, to understand protein folding dynamics related to the human body, to understand the mechanisms of enzyme catalysis to produce biofuels, and to identify and characterize gaseous species in the atmosphere. Because computational chemistry simulations can require large amounts of computer, memory and disk space, one focus of this research is to reduce the demands on computer resources by exploiting methods that can efficiently fragment large molecules into smaller pieces and at the same time take advantage of computers that have many thousands of computer cores. The principal investigators are developers of several computational chemistry programs, each of which has unique functionalities that have taken multiple person-years to develop and implement. In order to minimize further development efforts and to maximize the utility of the unique features, a second key focus of this research will be to develop the ability of each program to access the unique features and data of the other programs. A major bottleneck in the effort to construct high performance computers with more and more compute cores is the power that is required to drive such systems. One way that the research team will address the power issue is to explore the utility of low power architectures, such as graphical processing units for computational chemistry calculations. All of the newly developed codes will be made available to the user community by web download at no cost.  This project is supported by programs in the Division of Chemistry in MPS and the Division of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure in CISE. 

This project presents an integrated computational science approach to very high quality electronic structure and dynamics calculations that will (a) be broadly accessible to both the development and applications communities, (b) have the capability to address problems of great interest, such as the properties of liquids and solvent effects, and photochemical/photobiological dynamics with high accuracy, (c) provide interoperability and sustainability into the foreseeable future, and (d) solve bottlenecks including power consumption using accelerators. A primary goal is to provide to the broad community new, accurate approaches that may be easily used, with a clear path forward to further code improvement and development. As part of the proposed effort, in addition to the usual outlets of journal articles and public presentations, the investigators will organize workshops at prominent national meetings, so that the expertise and software developed will be available to as broad a group of users as possible.  All of the developed codes will be available on the web for easy downloads. The proposed research will develop new paradigms for interoperability, with a focus on the highly popular program suites GAMESS, NWChem, PSI4  and the AIMS dynamics code. Also included will be a cloud-based client-server model, a common quantum chemistry driver and novel data management approaches. The integration of the codes will be accomplished by making use of the combined expertise of the PIs in developing interoperable methods and data interfaces in computational science. In addition, several new methods will be developed, including novel explicit (R12) correlation methods that will be integrated with the most accurate levels of theory: multi-reference and the most accurate and novel coupled cluster methods, as well as the derivation and implementation of analytic derivatives. Applicability to large molecular systems will be made feasible by drawing upon novel fragmentation methods that scale nearly perfectly to the petascale.

Project Title: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: Removing Bottlenecks in High Performance Computational Science

 

We present an integrated computational science approach to very high quality electronic structure and dynamics calculations that will (a) be broadly accessible to both the development and applications communities, (b) have the capability to address problems of great interest, such as the properties of liquids and solvent effects, and photochemical/photobiological dynamics with high accuracy, (c) provide interoperability and sustainability into the foreseeable future, and (d) solve bottlenecks, including time to solution and power consumption, using accelerators. A primary goal is to provide to the broad scientific community new, accurate approaches that may be easily used, with a clear path forward to further code improvement and development. In addition to the usual outlets of journal articles and public presentations, we have organized workshops at prominent national meetings, so that the expertise and software developed is available to as broad a group of users as possible. All of the developed codes are available on the web for easy downloads. We have developed new paradigms for interoperability, with a focus on the highly popular program suites GAMESS, NWChem, and PSI4. Also included is a cloud-based client-server model, a common quantum chemistry driver and novel data management approaches. The integration of the codes was accomplished by making use of the combined expertise of the PIs in developing interoperable methods and data interfaces in computational science. A paper that reports the interoperability accomplishments is under review at the Journal of Chemical Physics. Applicability to large molecular systems is made feasible by drawing upon novel fragmentation methods that scale nearly perfectly to the petascale and beyond.

The interface between both GAMESS and NWChem (written in F77/F90) and LIBEFP (written in standard C99) was successfully completed for molecular systems containing only EFP fragments. The GAMESS-LIBEFP and NWChem-LIBEFP interfaces can accurately reproduce the LIBEFP results. The GAMESS-LIBEFP interface has been developed by former postdoctoral associate Nuwan DeSilva, who is now an Assistant Professor of Chemistry at Western New England University. Professor DeSliva has expanded his expertise into new areas. He has also benefitted from his interaction with the Slipchenko group who developed LIBEFP. Dr. DeSilva began an academic appointment as Assistant Professor at Western New England University in August 2017. His participation in this NSF project, and his collaborations with the Sherrill group has certainly helped him achieve his goals. Dr. DeSilva now has two undergraduate students doing research with him. In fact, he has already, in his second year as a member of the faculty, received an award for outstanding mentoring.

 

An invited feature article in the Journal of Physical Chemistry A on novel computer architectures and their impact on quantum chemistry has been published, with a cover that was designed by the authors.

A new invited paper on the GAMESS electronic structure code has been published in the Journal of Chemical Physics.

The QCDB software and its interface to multiple quantum chemistry codes is available on GitHub (https://github.com/qcdb/qcdb).

 

When she was a postdoc Dr. Emilie Guidez mentored two undergraduate students (one in chemistry and one in computer engineering) and one chemistry graduate student in the process of examining the ability of the EFP dispersion method to reproduce the intermolecular interactions in the S22 test set. Two papers that resulted from her activities have been published. Dr. Guidez has proven to be an excellent teacher and mentor. Dr. Guidez was awarded the ACS PHYS division postdoctoral theory award in Fall 2016. She began an appointment as Assistant Professor of Chemistry at the University of Colorado-Denver in the Fall 2017. She has two undergraduate students doing related research with her, a testament to her abilities as a teacher and mentor.

Dr. Joani Mato completed his PhD in summer 2019. He is now a postdoctoral researcher with Professor Guidez at the University of Colorado-Denver. He continues to collaborate on developments of the spin-correct spin flip method and is mentoring a first-year graduate student in the Gordon group on this project.

This work has been a collaboration of Iowa State University (lead organization), Georgia Tech, Old Dominion University, Purdue University, Stanford University and Virginia Tech.

Twenty two papers have been published based on the research supported by this National Science Foundation project.
